text:
Calling <@UJ2MQ8SRH> and any and all the other "small but mighty" content teams: I'm building a business case for continued content marketing team growth (currently 1 director, 1 content marketer/writer & freelance support for article production). For teams of less than five who've met or exceeded aggressive organic traffic growth goals, what were the major components for your strategy?

A couple of questions to get the convo going:
1. What was the mix between in-house content production and external vendor support? 
2. What are the specific content "swim lanes" (e.g., executive thought leadership, SEO focused articles) that ALWAYS stay in house?
3. Did you uses content agencies, writing services, or freelancers for external support? 
4. In your opinion, what's the key to unlocking scaled growth for organic traffic with a small team? 
Would love to hear from the community - or feel free to DM me if you'd rather discuss 1:1!

elements.text: Calling

A couple of questions to get the convo going:
What was the mix between in-house content production and external vendor support?
What are the specific content "swim lanes" (e.g., executive thought leadership, SEO focused articles) that ALWAYS stay in house?
Did you uses content agencies, writing services, or freelancers for external support?
In your opinion, what's the key to unlocking scaled growth for organic traffic with a small team?
Would love to hear from the community - or feel free to DM me if you'd rather discuss 1:1!

text:
i've scaled organic traffic on several sites with just 1 f/t in-house writer. a big part of it comes down to just choosing the right keywords.

i'm a big believer in not outsourcing on-site content. there's just too many benefits to in-house writers. i'd outsource content promotion though.

text:
<@U01EJ7VE9FD> what does your production output look like? Agree on the quality front, but we have huge volumes of opportunities, i.e., we need to produce quantity + quality.

I'm lucky to have significant resources, and I've developed a pretty awesome bench of freelancers (and potential freelancers) that I can entrust with high-quality, high-quantity output.

text: to put a specific number on it, in a situation like that i'd aim to publish 4-5 posts a week which is very doable with 1 f/t writer. "quality" is highly subjective, it all depends on your goals & whether the content achieves those goals

elements.text: to put a specific number on it, in a situation like that i'd aim to publish 4-5 posts a week which is very doable with 1 f/t writer. "quality" is highly subjective, it all depends on your goals & whether the content achieves those goals

text: ha, yes, for me quality is well-researched, well-written, well-optimized content that's not KW drivel :slightly_smiling_face:

text: 100%, my preference for freelancers really revolves around having the flexibility to turn the prod volume up or down when needed (without having to hire or fire FTEs)

text: I would suggest that a weekly reminder could be a mix of internal and external pieces. Articles about the industry as a whole, or about key competitors, or even just random fun stuff — along with internally-created pieces. Add value to the org by being a holistic info gathering operation.

elements.text: I would suggest that a weekly reminder could be a mix of internal and external pieces. Articles about the industry as a whole, or about key competitors, or even just random fun stuff — along with internally-created pieces. Add value to the org by being a holistic info gathering operation.

text:
*Content strategy Q coming in hot* :fire:
Hey everyone - this group has 100% made me better at content marketing so I welcome any and all advice/ thoughts :pray:

Context: when I joined Together our site was slowly declining because our best content was getting older and losing positions in the SERPs. I refreshed several blogs and they (for the most part) regained what they lost. Great success?!

Now that 10% that's bringing in most the traffic is declining again. So *here's my Q:*  Should I be as hyper-focused as I am on optimizing this handfull of blogs to make sure they're always growing or should I diversify and work on NEW content?

elements.text: Content strategy Q coming in hot
Hey everyone - this group has 100% made me better at content marketing so I welcome any and all advice/ thoughts

Context: when I joined Together our site was slowly declining because our best content was getting older and losing positions in the SERPs. I refreshed several blogs and they (for the most part) regained what they lost. Great success?!

Now that 10% that's bringing in most the traffic is declining again. So
here's my Q:
Should I be as hyper-focused as I am on optimizing this handfull of blogs to make sure they're always growing or should I diversify and work on NEW content?

text: I'd say it depends on how key those blogs are to your audience. If they're high converting as well as high traffic, then keep an eye on them, but if there are better opportunities to be found from a conversion perspective / they aren't providing traffic that's as relevant, I'd probably be less concerned.

elements.text: I'd say it depends on how key those blogs are to your audience. If they're high converting as well as high traffic, then keep an eye on them, but if there are better opportunities to be found from a conversion perspective / they aren't providing traffic that's as relevant, I'd probably be less concerned.

text: I need to figure out how to measure conversions from these! This is a good reminder!

elements.text: I need to figure out how to measure conversions from these! This is a good reminder!

text:
Lol this q looks familiar! I'll reply here as well:

Depends what base of traffic and conversions you're working from. If you have a lot of organic traffic (depends on industry, but over 100k/month) there could be good opportunity in updating old stuff.

If you have less than that you should probably focus on new content — the size of the opportunity there is larger

text:
I am currently a content team of one :woman-raising-hand: And utilize an agency, freelancers and our partner network to create content.

Contrary to discussion above, I prefer to have freelancers contribute at least some content to our site. Depending on your niche, having an outside perspective might produce _better_ content from a different viewpoint.

My main suggestion for you to is to think about how you can potentially leverage a partner network. I regularly work with power users/partners who want to write content. This is a great setup because their content is typically very high quality due to their expertise, but it can require a bit of hand holding. :slightly_smiling_face:

When scaling external resources, my biggest focus is on creating thorough, high quality content templates. That will help reduce wasted time and improve the quality of the article.

elements.text: I am currently a content team of one

content from a different viewpoint.

My main suggestion for you to is to think about how you can potentially leverage a partner network. I regularly work with power users/partners who want to write content. This is a great setup because their content is typically very high quality due to their expertise, but it can require a bit of hand holding.
When scaling external resources, my biggest focus is on creating thorough, high quality content templates. That will help reduce wasted time and improve the quality of the article.

text:
That's an interesting question, and as someone who has spent a lot of years in the services/consulting world, it kind of reminds me of reasoning about your book of business.  Conventional wisdom says it's ideal not to have any one client accounting for more than 20% of gross revenue, because it's a risk.  If you have a few whale clients, it's a much bigger gut punch if one leaves, and you wind up redefining your practice to cater to the whales, rather than to cater to broader growth.

Inasmuch as the metaphor works, the question becomes one of short term and long term risk.  Ignoring new content to keep the whales going is a short term payoff with long term risk, whereas the other strategy has more short term risk and long term payoff.  Assuming you can't address both, that is.

elements.text:
That's an interesting question, and as someone who has spent a lot of years in the services/consulting world, it kind of reminds me of reasoning about your book of business.  Conventional wisdom says it's ideal not to have any one client accounting for more than 20% of gross revenue, because it's a risk.  If you have a few whale clients, it's a much bigger gut punch if one leaves, and you wind up redefining your practice to cater to the whales, rather than to cater to broader growth.

Inasmuch as the metaphor works, the question becomes one of short term and long term risk.  Ignoring new content to keep the whales going is a short term payoff with long term risk, whereas the other strategy has more short term risk and long term payoff.  Assuming you can't address both, that is.

text: Anyway, that said, I :100: agree with <@ULJBEFSJJ> that the real thing to measure isn't the traffic as much as down-funnel metrics closer to revenue.  Assuming those figures mirror traffic, I'd look at the same long-term/short-term tradeoff

elements.text: Anyway, that said, I
agree with
that the real thing to measure isn't the traffic as much as down-funnel metrics closer to revenue.  Assuming those figures mirror traffic, I'd look at the same long-term/short-term tradeoff

text:
Swim lanes would include internal linking, headlines and headline testing, and taking the lead on topic brainstorming. 

External writers interviewing internal experts can bring some fresh ideas. 

Growth comes from ongoing promotion, building out complete coverage of a topic that’s well cross linked, and updating existing content to maintain your edge.

elements.text: Swim lanes would include internal linking, headlines and headline testing, and taking the lead on topic brainstorming.
External writers interviewing internal experts can bring some fresh ideas.
Growth comes from ongoing promotion, building out complete coverage of a topic that’s well cross linked, and updating existing content to maintain your edge.

text: Look at the content that’s outranking your laggards. Can you make improvements to make yours significantly better?

elements.text: Look at the content that’s outranking your laggards. Can you make improvements to make yours significantly better?

text:
At Eventbrite in 2016, we were three content marketing managers and a managing editor doing it all in-house. A year in and we were partnering with other brands to collaborate and share duties, some written entirely by Eventbrite’s team, some written by the partner’s. Some time after that, if I recall correctly, we started to lean on contract writers. By 2018, the three content marketing managers were purely strategist working with a pool of 4-5 contract writers, managing a few contributors, and aligning strategies with regional content strategists who had either employed an agency or contractors. Between 2019-2020, an agency dedicated to case studies, another doing syndication, and one tackling translation/localization were added to the mix. 

There was never a clear cut segmentation of what work was entrusted to whom. The pool of writers would get developed to the point I was able to lean on a few to handle an entire ebook — research, outline, draft, and all — if needed. 

The key to unlocking growth has already been said. But to put a different spin on it, content marketing used to be a blue ocean strategy. I vividly recall publishing a blog post to the Eventbrite blog on a Tuesday afternoon and see it ranked #1 on Google Wednesday morning. 

That’s literally impossible today. I’m on mobile but these stats are (iconically) readily available from a Google search. 
• 90% of content never ranks on Google. 
• 65% of the stuff that does never gets a click. 
• Less than 1% of the audiences brands worked their asses off the build are reachable. 
• It’s better on Instagram but more abysmal on Twitter and LI
. 
• 88% of iOS users opted out of tracking. 
• Paid CTR continues to nose dive, leading brands to squeeze blood from fucking turnips. 
So you can choose your own adventure and go with any possible mix of in-house, agency, contributors, contractors — but when it comes down to brass tacks, the only way your content has a chance of earning a mere fraction of the attention it would have gotten 5-7 years ago is with a documented strategy that has a realistic chance of reaching past the gate keepers and resonates in an ocean of platform-native content.

Between 2019-2020, an agency dedicated to case studies, another doing syndication, and one tackling translation/localization were added to the mix. 

There was never a clear cut segmentation of what work was entrusted to whom. The pool of writers would get developed to the point I was able to lean on a few to handle an entire ebook — research, outline, draft, and all — if needed. 

The key to unlocking growth has already been said. But to put a different spin on it, content marketing used to be a blue ocean strategy. I vividly recall publishing a blog post to the Eventbrite blog on a Tuesday afternoon and see it ranked #1 on Google Wednesday morning.

So you can choose your own adventure and go with any possible mix of in-house, agency, contributors, contractors — but when it comes down to brass tacks, the only way your content has a chance of earning a mere fraction of the attention it would have gotten 5-7 years ago is with a documented strategy that has a realistic chance of reaching past the gate keepers and resonates in an ocean of platform-native content.
